intro: Linkia levis, commonly known as the slender sea hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the coastal regions of the Indo-Pacific. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its fleshy, succulent leaves and showy, five-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows in shallow marine environments, such as tidal zones and sandy shores, where it thrives in brackish water conditions. Its roots are adapted to stabilize sediments and prevent erosion, making it ecologically significant in coastal ecosystems. The flowers are pollinated by various marine invertebrates and small fish, contributing to its role in marine biodiversity.
